awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2017: Do sick frogs increase reproductive investment? A behavioral and physiological examination of the terminal investment hypothesis
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology, under the program Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellow, Talisin Hammond, is conducting research and receiving training that increases the participation of groups underrepresented in biology, at the University of Pittsburgh, and is being mentored by Cori Richards-Zawicki (sponsoring scientist). This research explores how the reproductive behavior and physiology of multiple species of frogs is affected by chytridiomycosis, a fungal disease that has decimated many amphibian populations. In addition to improving our understanding of how this disease impacts amphibians, which are currently highly threatened by numerous environmental factors, this work also clarifies the role of sub-lethal effects of disease on population dynamics and evolutionary processes.  As part of this project the fellow is working with a natural history museum to teach student groups about science using sketch-noting. The fellow is also designing a research-based educational module, which will be freely available, and is working with an online network to find educators interested in its implementation. Finally, the fellow is mentoring diverse undergraduate students.

Wildlife diseases impact populations both directly, through mortality, and indirectly, through sub-lethal changes to host biology. Disease-induced fatalities can be devastating, but sub-lethal changes in behavior and physiology also have the potential to exert substantial pressure on populations. The terminal investment hypothesis, which states that animals with decreasing future reproductive potential should invest more in immediate reproduction, predicts that sick animals with decreased longevity should elevate reproductive effort, and that species with higher susceptibility should increase effort more. The fellow's research is testing this hypothesis, focusing on chytridiomycosis as the disease agent. The processes by which this disease kills amphibians are better-understood than its sub-lethal impacts, and few studies have experimentally described how chytridiomycosis impacts reproductive behavior and physiology. This project uses three congeneric frog species with differing disease susceptibility, using call recordings, behavioral choice tests, and hormonal manipulations in conjunction with quantifications of pathogen load, immune function and spermatic traits to characterize how the disease affects male reproductive behavior and physiology, and female preference. This work is generating novel insights into the role of sub-lethal, disease-mediated behavioral and physiological effects on individuals.  In addition to providing training support for the fellow in a new field of study, this work also involves significant outreach, including teaching student groups visiting natural history museums, developing a research-related, online-available educational module, and mentoring diverse undergraduate students.

por.por_cntn:
Like many taxonomic groups, amphibian species are currently experiencing catastrophic declines worldwide. One shared cause of many amphibian declines is the invasive fungal pathogen Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd). Bd can have direct impacts on amphibian populations by causing morbidity. Less well understood are the indirect and sublethal impacts of Bd, and how these effects may contribute to demographic patterns. These effects may manifest as behavioral or physiological changes which can have cascading impacts on fitness. During this fellowship the PI conducted studies related to Bd, behavior, physiology, and amphibian conservation in four Ranid frogs.

This fellowship was initially hosted by Bd expert Dr. Cori Richards-Zawacki at the University of Pittsburgh. Here, the PI worked to validate and publish a new method for non-invasively monitoring glucocorticoid (GC) secretion across multiple amphibian species using saliva. The PI then studied relationships between Bd status and both baseline and acutely elevated GCs in both field and lab settings across species of differing Bd susceptibility, documenting differing Bd-GC relationships in a more Bd susceptible species. The PI also characterized relationships between Bd, GCs, and behavior across species. In fall of 2018 there was an approved change of scope and transfer of host institutions for this project with the aim of gaining more applied experience in conservation. Dr. Ron Swaisgood and Dr. Debra Shier at the San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance served as hosts for a project focusing on Bd dynamics and behavior in the mountain yellow-legged frog (Rana muscosa). This transfer gave the PI sought-after training and experience in working with reintroductions of an endangered species and with state, federal, and non-governmental agencies. Work was first conducted to develop new detection methods this cryptic species in the wild to facilitate future studies. Extensive mark-recapture data were collected using traditional visual surveys and using a long-range microchip reader, and Bayesian open population models were created to document significantly improved detection rates. This published work also began to identify factors that altered detection rates related to behavioral phenotypes. The PI collected behavioral data from hundreds of individuals across multiple years, documenting impacts of pre-reintroduction treatments and behaviors on post-reintroduction success. Work was then conducted to monitor Bd in focal populations at times of year where historical sampling has not been conducted (e.g. late fall through early spring). The PI contributed to the collection of hundreds of Bd swabs each year and multiple Bd-related die-off events, primarily in fall/winter, were documented as a part of this work. New efforts are targeting Bd as a major threat limiting re-establishment of this species. The PI also conducted work to swab historical museum specimens and to validate saliva GC monitoring in this species, however, these studies required lab access and travel, which were hindered by the COVID-19 pandemic. Thus, this work is still in progress. Results from this research will contribute to a better understanding of the role of behavior in amphibian conservation and disease ecology, and in understanding and mitigating the impacts of Bd on an endangered species, the mountain yellow-legged frog.

During the fellowship tenure the PI co-authored 14 peer-reviewed publications, 5 of which included co-authors that were undergraduate students at the time of the work (3 additional manuscripts are in preparation/in review, all involving undergraduate co-authors). The PI also gave numerous talks at conferences and meetings, as well as invited lectures in higher-education classrooms (including live sketch-noting activities to integrate art into the sciences). The PI gained valuable training in lab methods related to disease ecology, in designing large, multi-factorial behavioral/physiological experiments, in grant-writing, and in working in applied conservation science.

Broader impacts and outreach work aimed at broadening participation in the sciences was a major part of this fellowship. During this fellowship the PI mentored 9 undergraduate students, mainly from backgrounds underrepresented in the sciences, involving students in all stages of the scientific process, and providing guidance on graduate school applications. Mentorship took place in part with the Doris Duke Conservation Scholars Program and the San Diego Zoo Wildlife Alliance Summer Fellows Program. The PI also participated in extensive outreach activities with K-12 students, including with the Carnegie Museum. Many activities integrated art and science to appeal to students with diverse interests. The COVID-19 pandemic made outreach more challenging, but work continued through virtual classroom visits (e.g. through Skype a Scientist, Scientist in Every Florida School Primetime Summer Series, SDZWA STEM Conservation Careers classroom visits, and with Zoom calls to local middle school classrooms nearby to field sites). Educational module development and interfacing with K-12 teachers also were prioritized, e.g., via sharing a module on QUBES Hub; a San Diego County Office of Education Environmental Phenomena Summit linking local researchers and teachers for module development; and a talk and activity with an NSF Research Experience for Teachers program (led by Dr. Richards-Zawacki).
